cleaned_text: ABSTRACT This chapter examines the case for vaccines and shows that vaccines are essential for preventing outbreaks and appeals to widespread exceptions for parental choice undermine herd immunity. It argues that a recovery of rationality in the vaccine debate. In 1998, Dr. Andrew Wakefield published an essay in the Lancet, a respected British medical journal, claiming a connection between the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine and autism. The MMR vaccine is an unrivaled success story. In the United States, vaccination rates are in steady decline; specifically, many parents are opting out of the MMR, putting herd immunity for many diseases at risk and causing outbreaks of measles, once thought vanquished due to vaccines. The anti-vaccination movement is particularly puzzling because skeptics make for strange bedfellows: Conservatives support parental choice and well-educated progressives repudiate what they see as toxic injections.
